description: P(A) >= 0 for all events A
title: probability is greater than 0 for all events

description: total probability = 1
title: total probability = 1

description: For every infinite sequence of disjoint events A1 ... An the P(union of all events) = sum of all probabilities of events
title: summation of events = summation of probabilities (addition rule)

description: P(Ac) = 1 - P(A)
title: complement of A

description: If A in B then Pr(A) <= Pr(B)
title: Pr(A) <= Pr(B) if A in B

description: Pr(empty set) = 0
title: Pr(empty set) = 0

description: probability on a sample space S is a specification of numbers Pr(A) for all events that satisfy Axioms 1 2 and 3.
title: probability

description: for every two events A and B Pr(A intersection Bc) = Pr(A) - Pr(A intersection B)
title: Pr(A intersection Bc) = Pr(A) - Pr(A intersection B)

description: Pr(A union B) = Pr(A) + Pr(B) - Pr(A intersection B)
title: Pr(A union B) = Pr(A) + Pr(B) - Pr(A intersection B)

description: Bonferroni inequality is P(union Ai) <= sum of P(Ai) and P(intersection Ai) >= 1- sum(P(Aic)
title: Bonferroni inequality

description: a finite sample space is where S is every outcome is equally likely
title: simple sample space

description: multiplication rule is if a job consists of k parts (k >= 2) and the ith part has ni possible outcomes regardless of what outcomes came before then the job can be done in n1 x n2 x ... x nk ways
title: multiplication rule

description: ordered samples without replacement is n
title: ordered samples without replacement

description: unordered samples without replacement is Cnk = (n k) = n
title: unordered samples without replacement

description: ordered samples with replacement is just n^k
title: ordered samples with replacement

description: unordered samples with replacement is (n+k-1 k)
title: unordered samples with replacement

description: binomial coefficient is the number of ways to choose k items out of n without replacement. (n k) = n
title: binomial coefficient

description: binomial theorem is (x+y)^n = sum[n k](n k)x^k * y^(n-k)
title: binomial theorem

description: multinomial coefficient is number of ways to divide n items into k different groups or (n n1...nk) = n
title: multinomial coefficient

description: multinomial theorem is (x1 + x2 + ... xk)^n = sum[n1...nk = n](n n1...nk)x1^n1 * x2^n2 * ... * xk^nk
title: multinomial theorem

description: conditional probability of event A given that event B has occured is P(A|B) = P(A intersection B)/P(B) if P(B) > 0
title: conditional probability

description: Pr(A|B) is computed as the proportion of total probability Pr(B) that is represented by Pr(A intersection B). intuitively the proportion of B that is also part of A
title: the proportion of B that is also part of A

description: partition is for S a sample space A1 ... Ak are disjoint and U[i infinity]Ai = S then the collection A1 A2 ... is called the partition of S
title: partition

description: sample space S
title: sample space S

description: law of total probability states that if B1...Bk forma  partition of the sample space S and P(Bj) > 0 for all j then for every event A in S: P(A) = sum[j=1 k] P(Bj)P(A|Bj)
title: law of total probability

description: Bayes' Theorem states that if B1...Bk form a partition of S and P(Bj) > 0 for all j and P(A) > 0 then P(Bi|A) = P(Bi)P(A|Bi)/sum[j=1 k]P(Bj)P(A|Bj). The denomiator can also be written as P(A). The numerator is equal to P(Bi intersection A)
title: Bayes' Theorem

description: independence states that two events A and B are said to be statistically inindependent then P(A| intersection B) = P(A) * P(B)
title: independent events

description: consequence of independence of A and B then P(A|B) = P(A intersection B)/P(B) = P(A)P(B)/P(B) = P(A). As well as P(B |A) = P(B)
title: conditional probabilities for independent events are just probabilities

description: if A and B are independent then A and Bc or Ac and B or Ac and Bc are all indpependent as well
title: complements are independent

description: mutually independent events are when A1...Ak if for every subset Ai1 ... Aij j = 2...k then P(Ai1 intersection ... Aij) = P(Ai1) x ... x P(Aij)
title: mutually independent events

description: P(A inter B inter C) = P(A)P(B)P(C) does not imply mutual independence. Pairwise independence does not imply mutual independence
title: mutual independence is not

description: conditional independence given B is for every subset Ai1...Aij of A1...Ak then P(Ai1 intersection ... Aij|B) = P(Ai1|B) x ... x P(Aij|B)
title: conditional independence

description: random variable is a function from a sample space S to the real numbers R. P(X = xi) = P({sj in S: X(sj) = xi} where xi in A
title: random variable

description: support of X is the range of X
title: support of random variable

description: random variable X is said to have a discrete distribution if X can only take countable number of different values
title: discrete random variable
